bboxes.raw_text:
NEW YORK James R. Dump
son, a Negro, has been serving
as the city welfare commissioner
since 1859. At IS. he is in charge
of % welfare offices, whose per-
sonnet distributes assistance to
more than 100000 persons. This
load increases by 5000 cases
monthly.


Dumpson has been nicknamed
Little Dynamite" because ofhis
long hours at his desk.


Of those getting welfare aid.
food. rent or medical care, nearly
rs per cent are Negroes and
Puerto Ricans. The total New
York City population is estimated
at 5000. 900: 100000 are Me-
groes and 675, 900 are Puerto Ri
cans.


The ma jor cause for the num-
Der of Negroes and Puerto Ricans
on the welfare rolls is caused by
the continuous flow of unskilled
and poorly educated Negroes
from the South and Puerto Ricans
from Puerto Rico.


The commissioner states that
Nobody has too much respect
for dependency. land we attack
people who are dependent, rather
than the cause of their depen-
dency."

Negro Heads NY
W eIfure Dept.

CHICAGO-N P) Plans to ship
by air 10000 turkeys to Negroes
in Mississippi for Christmas
have been arranged by Dick Gre
CORY, nationally known comedian,
and Mrs. Fannie Lou Hamer,
who addressed the Democratic
National Convention concerning
the terrible Mississippi condi-
tons.


Mrs. Hamer said that she was
Al years old and had eaten only
one turkey in her life and that
was more than five years ago.


She continued that she bought
the bird on the insta llment plan
and 1t took eight months to pay
for 1t. The white man who owned
the store where she got credit
is no longer In business.


Gregory commented that cot
ton picking was scarce because
of the bad weather and that most
of the Negroes living In the rural
areas are penniless and hungry.


Inquiries and donations should
be mailed to Christmas for Mis-
sissippi, P. O. Box 1897, Chi
cago, Illinois.

Hope, Ark, is visiting her son
in law and daughter, Mr.. and Mrs.
Fred Holloway.


Mrs. Barbara Osborne of
Houston spent a few days here
before going to Los Angeles.
Plan to attend the annual Sun
ceray Social Clubs New Years
Eve dance. President Bernice.
Oates said it will be the best
affair of the new year.


Mrs. Asava Woods, president,
announces the women 8 auxiliary
OF the Veterans of Foreign War,
Post l7l0, will hold It's annual
Christmas party, Dec. 40, for
children only.


The Debonairs will hold IT'S
holiday party and birthday party
Sat-, Dec. 10. They would like
to get in contact with all patrons
who attended the Sadie Hawkins
Dance. The members have a
surprise for them. Contact a
Debonair as soon as you can.


Thanks for making the first
weekly sing of the Willing Work
ers a success. Everyone was
grand to pitch in.


Thought of the week Good
things are not cheap and cheap
things are not good.


Sign of Times


The following sign is post
ed on the marquee of his
toric Los Angeles theater,
currently being razed: "Now
Playing, Cleveland Wreck
ing Co., Show With a Bang"

Telephone Directory Delivery
Workers are needed. Interviews
will be held Tues, Dec. %, Sam
5 pm. (only). 438 w. Adams St.

Congratulations and best
wishes for success to Rosie
Turman, newly elected exalted
ruler of w. H. Patterson Elks
Lodge. and Mrs. Lillian Fit,
new daughter ruler.


Hats off to the Merry Mixers
they donated SIS to the St. Vim
cent de Paul Society for Christ
mas charity.


Sixty youngsters enjoyed the
Debonairs annual Christina par
ty Saturday at Eastlake Park.
Santa was Robert Price, Jr., who
was assisted in giving gifts by
Teresa Williams, club Miss
Teen.


Each child received two toys
and plenty of refreshments.


Mrs. Celia Lewis has returned
home from attending funeral rites
of her father, Rev. Miles Clark
in Arkansas.


Mrs. Blanche Hunter, mother
of Bonnie Hunter passed away
in California. Her rites will be
held in Phoenix.


Jerry Oliver has received a
scholarship to Arizona State
University. Good Luck.


Mrs. Clardene Bradley of

during recording Evangelist Ceophus Robinson

ooist the recording OF jesus

Bdrm. Apt.

add piquancy to flavor.

full articles.headline:
All Around

BY FLORA RuFFIN
